Fig. 1 (a) XRD patterns (b) HRTEM and selected area electron diffraction (SAED) images, and (c) NH3-TPD of as-synthesized catalysts. These results indicate successful inclusion of Fe and Co into the BCN catalyst. Additionally, lattice planes of iron and cobalt oxides suggest the presence of their oxides. Importantly, in NH3-TPD, Co-BCN catalyst exhibit relatively less acidic sites, which enables facile desorption of generated ammonia from the catalyst surface. All tested catalysts display NH3 desorption peak near 692 °C. Fig 1 Fig. 2 Narrow spectra of (a) C1s (b) N1s (c) B1s in BCN, Fe-BCN, and Co-BCN catalysts. (d) Fe2p spectra in Fe-BCN (e) Co2p spectra in Co-BCN. Fig 2 Fig. 3 The effect of process parameters. (a) feed ratio (N2:H2), (b) total gas flow rate (ml min−1), and (c) specific energy input (SEI). This study finds that the maximum rate of ammonia generation can be achieved with a feed (i) close to the stoichiometric ratio in the H-B process, (ii) at low residence time, and (iii) with high-energy electrons. Note: All of these experiments were performed without the use of catalysts. Fig 3 Fig. 4 Comparative ammonia synthesis performance of as-synthesized catalysts at (a) 40 ml min−1, and (b) 120 ml min−1 (Conditions: 17.28 kJL−1 and 20.16 kJL−1, feed ratio (N2: H2) = 1:3, time = 10 min, catalyst weight = 1.0 g). Fig 4 Fig. 5 IR study for ammonia synthesis. (a) blank, and (b) with Co-BCN (Conditions: 40 ml min−1, feed ratio N2:H2 (1:3), 17.28 kJ L−1 SEI, 10 min reaction time). The effluent stream from the DBD reactor was directed to the FTIR instrument equipped with Harrick praying mantis chamber, and the data from gaseous phase was collected at a definite interval. (c) relative intensity changes for the signal at 930 cm−1 in the recorded IR spectra for blank and Co-BCN tests during N2 H2 reaction upon NTP (Inset: Plasma-ignition condition to illustrate the synergistic role of the catalytic material). Intensity of signal at 930 cm−1 corresponds to 100 %. Fig 5 Fig. 6 (a) XRD pattern of the used catalysts, (b) Comparative FTIR spectra of representative fresh and spent Co-BCN catalysts (c) XPS N1s narrow scan spectra for fresh and spent (i) BCN and (ii) Co-BCN catalysts. The deconvolution of XPS spectrum of spent catalysts indicate the presence of CNH x (x = 1,2) species on the surface. Apparently, spent Co-BCN catalyst offers relatively weaker acidic sites and hence, less -NH species are adsorbed to the surface. (d) TG/DTA data for fresh and spent Co-BCN catalyst. The spent catalysts demonstrate no apparent change in the structural and chemical composition below 100 °C. Also, water desorption from the surface leads to the initial weight loss in the as-prepared catalysts subjected to heat under argon flow. Fig 6 Fig. 7 illustrates a pictorial representation of a possible mechanism for NTP-assisted catalytic synthesis of ammonia. Initially, H2 (g) and N2 (g) are dissociated by NTP and get adsorbed on the surface of catalyst. According to the Langmuir-Hinshelwood (L-H) mechanism (route1), these adsorbed species then react to generate ammonia. Furthermore, acidic sites of the catalyst help to readily desorb ammonia, described as weak acid sites in this figure. For instance, Co-species facilitate ammonia desorption, as suggested by NH3-TPD. Interestingly, controlled experiments disclose that the N in BCN could also contribute to ammonia generation, corresponding to the Mars-van Krevelen (MvK) mechanism (route 2). The anion vacancies (shown as V, here) and lattice N3− participate in the reaction, which mediate the MvK mechanism. Importantly, these vacancies accept plasma-dissociated N to regenerate the lattice N of the catalyst. We report nonthermal plasma-assisted catalytic ammonia synthesis from N2 and H2 molecules at near ambient conditions in a custom-built coaxial dielectric barrier discharge plasma reactor. Here, we strategically designed catalysts to facilitate dissociation of strong nitrogen bond and desorption of NH3 molecules. This work demonstrates the use of empty orbitals of boron doped in graphitic carbon nitride (BCN) to activate nitrogen molecules, by creating electron-deficient sites, under nonthermal plasma conditions. Transition metals (Co and Fe) further contribute to the ammonia generation by altering the amount of weak acid sites of the BCN catalyst. As a result, at 20.16 kJ L−1, the maximum ammonia synthesis rate of ∼ 2.48 m m o l g − 1 h − 1 was achieved by Co-BCN that corresponds to energy efficiency of 2.09 g-NH3 kWh−1, which was ca. 2.89-folds higher than that of plasma only. Evidently, dual mechanisms at play, leading to enhanced ammonia synthesis rates. Our strategy of tailoring catalyst structure provides a roadmap for engineering synergy with nonthermal plasma towards targeted applications. Introduction Ammonia (NH3) is a key raw material for the production of essential compounds, such as fertilizer, nitric acid, insecticides, and others [1–3]. Anhydrous NH3 has high gravimetric (∼17.0 wt. %) and volumetric (∼0.1 kg//liter at 25 °C) capacities and, therefore, is attractive to be a potential hydrogen carrier for onboard storage [4]. Recently, NH3 has generated a lot of interest owing to its high energy density and zero carbon-emission capability, which offers enormous potential as an energy source [5,6]. In fact, the liquefaction of ammonia is performed at 1.0 MPa and 298 K, which requires relatively less energy and, hence, suitable for the storage and transportation purposes [7,8]. In industries, ammonia is manufactured by the well-accepted Haber-Bosch (H-B) process, which requires extreme conditions (e.g., 400 °C, 200 atm) [9,10] . Because stable nitrogen molecules (NN, 948 kJ/mol) need high energy to dissociate, which, actually consume ∼2 % of the total world's energy to produce ammonia at a global scale. Since conventional methods require huge energy, other emerging technologies, such as photocatalysis [11–14], plasma-catalysis [15–19], thermal catalysis [20,21], (photo-) electrocatalysis [22,23] have been rapidly developed for production of ammonia. Nonthermal plasma (NTP) for nitrogen fixation into ammonia is an interesting technique for operation at small scale, owing to its sustainable properties [24,25]. Unlike thermal plasma, NTP has non-equilibrium characteristic, which means that most of the energy supplied to the NTP is utilized to produce energized electrons and reactive species, rather than heating the background gas [26]. For instance, various methods such as dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) [25], micro discharge [27], radio frequency discharge [28], and glow discharge plasmas [29] are used for ammonia generation. Plasma catalysis process exhibits better performance; however, the underlying synergy between plasma and catalysts is still not clearly understood. Within the literature, it is evident that properties such as surface area, dielectric constant, particle size, and vacancy fraction of catalysts govern the plasma discharge. For example, Shah et al. illustrated the role of acidic sites of the catalytic material, Zeolite-5A, for production of ammonia (Javishk R. [30]) . The work reports an energy yield of 15.5 gNH3 kWh−1 ammonia formation using Zeolite-5A, which was at least fifty-times higher than that without the catalysts. In another study, addition of Mg in SBA-15 promoted the ammonia production under the NTP conditions [18]. Specifically, as-fabricated Ni-Mg0.02/SBA-15-IWI catalyst demonstrated the ammonia generation rate and energy efficiency of 4.4 mmolh−1 g−1 and 1.05 gNH3 kWh−1, respectively. This result was attributed to the ability of Mg to uniformly distribute Ni active sites on the surface of as-prepared catalyst that increased the interaction of Ni and SBA-15 support. Similarly, other catalysts such as 5 % Ru/α-Al2O3 (S. [31]) and Ru-Ti-CeO2 [25] are recently explored in a fixed-bed DBD reactor. Notably, TiO2 in the Ru-Ti-CeO2 catalyst provided more surface for hydrogen adsorption, which helped in suppressing hydrogen poisoning effect of Ru metals. It is also understood that surface reactions of catalysts play a decisive role in determining the performance of NTP-assisted reactions, which is not only limited to NH3 synthesis [32,33]. Therefore, transition metals are increasingly employed. For example, Wang et al. tested the plasma-catalytic activity of M/Al2O3 (M= Fe, Ni, and Cu) towards NH3 synthesis and reported superior performance of Ni/Al2O3, with about 15.2 % greater rates than that of Fe/Al2O3 [34]. Importantly, activity of noble metals was also examined by Patil et al., and revealed that Ru was most efficient, followed by Rh and Ni [35]. Mo and Pd were inferior towards NTP NH3 synthesis. In another work, Zhu et al. investigated the role of supports and found that Ru-loaded activated carbon significantly increased the NH3 synthesis rate than that over alumina or silica [36]. Ru/activated carbon demonstrated the maximum NH3 yield of 1544 ppm at 50 mL min−1, 9 W of discharge power, and equal feed ratio of N2 and H2. Moreover, Mehta et al. postulated that vibrations induced in nitrogen by NTP, decreases the dissociation barriers but does not influence the subsequent hydrogenation steps and desorption of ammonia molecules [37]. Wang et al. discussed the catalytic approach to minimize the decomposition of formed ammonia during the NTP-assisted ammonia synthesis process using Ni-based MCM-41 mesoporous catalyst in a DBD reactor. The study revealed that the use of mesoporous catalysts improved the production rate of ammonia by providing shielding protection as mesopores are plasma inactive [38]. Garky et al. also reported for the partial protection of formed ammonia decomposition during NTP process by applying CC3, a porous oraganic cage catalyst in a DBD reactor. They used CC3 based membrane as well to adsorb and desorb the ammonia to elude NH3 decomposition [39]. Further, Rouwenhorst et al. verified this postulation with the additional experimental results for alumina-supported ruthenium catalysts [40]. Based on these studies, it can be concluded that the main issue`s related to the NTP NH3 synthesis are: (i) dissociation of strong nitrogen bond, and (ii) prevention of undesired back reactions (such as quick dissociation of ammonia after being formed) [41], and (iii) easy desorption of NH3 molecules. To address the aforementioned challenges, reactors with provision to readily separate ammonia can be used, together with catalysts exhibiting synergistic role with NTP. Moreover, it is envisaged that creation of electron-deficient sites by embedding heteroatoms with small electronegativity values than carbon, can change the microelectronic structure and consequently, activate the N2 molecules [42]. In specific, heteroatoms can change the π* orbitals and reduce the bond order of the N2 molecules [43]. Herein, we demonstrate the use of boron-doped graphitic carbon nitride (BCN) as an active catalyst for generation of ammonia in the presence of nonthermal plasma. In particular, this work intends to address the challenge of readily dissociating strong N2 molecules. In the as-designed catalyst, the boron atom has empty orbitals (2s22p1) and can efficiently bind or activate inert N2 molecules [44]. Additionally, surface nitrogen vacancies in graphitic carbon nitride can readily attract electrons of nearby carbon atoms, making them electron-deficient sites and consequently, enhancing the nitrogen activation process [42]. To further enhance the activity, we doped the BCN with iron and cobalt oxide particles, because of their ability to dissociate N2 molecules ([45,46]) and desorb NH3 molecules. Accordingly, the effect of this strategy in increasing the catalytic activity for ammonia synthesis under nonthermal plasma conditions is thoroughly examined, with systematic infrared spectroscopy studies for identifying the active species during the process. Experimental procedure Ammonia synthesis reaction conducted in a custom-designed co-axial di-electric barrier discharge reactor (DBD) in non-thermal plasma (NTP) atmosphere. The DBD reactor has two concentric tubes, made of quartz. The outer tube has 25 mm (inner diameter, I.D.) and 28 mm (outer diameter, O.D.), which was wrapped by stainless steel mesh and serve as a ground electrode. The discharge length of the DBD reactor was equivalent to the stainless-steel mesh length (∼140 mm). The internal tube worked as a high voltage electrode by inserting stainless steel foil inside it. The specification for the inner tube is having 18 mm (I.D.) and 20 mm (O.D.). After assembling the concentric tubes, the DBD reactor achieved 2.5 mm (discharge gap) and 140 mm (discharge length). AC current that was controlled by a plasma generator was used to create the discharge (Manufacturer: Arshad Electronics Pvt. Ltd., Mumbai, India) by applying high voltage 10–15 kV at 50 Hz. Mass flow controllers (MFC) (Make: Brooks) were employed to regulate the reactant gases (nitrogen and hydrogen) flow rate to the DBD reactor. Firstly, the optimization of reaction parameters for ammonia synthesis such as DBD power, total gas flow rate and feed ratio of reactants, were done before testing the catalytic performances. To identify the optimum power, the current supplied to the DBD reactor was varied from 0.8 A to 1.4 A, at total flow rate of 40 ml min−1 for 1:3 feed ratio (N2:H2). Similarly, to optimize the total gas flow rate, the N2:H2 feed ratio was kept constant at 1:3 and current was fixed at 1.2 A. Notably, the range of total gas flow rate was 40 ml min−1 −120 ml min−1. Lastly, the N2:H2 feed ratio was changed from 2:1 to 1:5 to obtain the optimum value of feed ratio. In these experiments, current was kept at 1.2 A and the total gas flow rate was 80 ml/min. To identify ammonia generation, titration method was used. In which, the vent gas was flown into 10 ml of 2.5 mM sulphuric acid (H2SO4) solution, where the colour change was examined using methyl orange as an indicator. When the sulphuric acid solution was completely neutralized by ammonia, pink colour of then solution turned yellow. Further, conductivity method was employed to quantify the production rate of ammonia. In which, generated ammonia was captured in a solution of 1.2 mM H2SO4, and the production rate of ammonia was calculated by measuring the difference in proton conductivity by a conductivity meter (Make: Mettler Toledo Seven Multi). Formula used: (i) A m m o n i a f o r m a t i o n r a t e ( μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 ) = C o n c e n t r a t i o n o f a m m o n i a f o r m e d ( μ m o l ) C a t a l y s t w t . ( g ) × t i m e ( h ) (ii) A m m o n i a y i e l d ( % ) = a m m o n i a f o r m a t i o n r a t e ( μ m o l / h ) 2 × m o l e s o f n i t r o g e n i n r e a c t a n t s t r e a m ( μ m o l / h ) (iii) S p e c i f i c e n e r g y i n p u t ( S E I , J L − 1 ) = P ( w ) X 60 V o l u m e t r i c f l o w r a t e ( m l / m i n ) (iv) E n e r g y E f f i c i e n c y ( g − N H 3 k W h − 1 ) = C o n c e n t r a t i o n o f a m m o n i a ( m o l ) X V o l u m e t r i c f l o w r a t e ( m l / m i n ) X M P ( k W ) Where, M= Molecular weight of ammonia (17 g mol−1) Catalysts synthesis To prepare 10 wt. % boron-doped graphitic carbon nitride (BCN), 4 g of dicyandiamide (Sigma Aldrich, 99 % purity) was mixed in deionized water (200 ml) and stirred for 15 min at 80 °C. Further, 0.5 g of boric acid (EMPARTA, 99.5 % purity) was added to the solution and again stirred at 500 rpm for 15 min. The obtained mixture was placed in an oven at 90 °C overnight. The obtained solid powder was placed in an alumina boat and calcined in a muffle furnace at 520 °C with a ramp rate of 2.75 °C min−1 for 1 h. Finally, the calcined sample was crushed, thoroughly washed, and subjected to 90 °C for overnight to obtain BCN catalyst. Next, for synthesis of 10 wt. % iron oxide-loaded BCN (Fe-BCN), 0.5 g of iron chloride hexahydrate (Sigma, 99.5 % pure) was stirred in a deionized water (50 ml) and ultra-sonicated for 5 min. Further, the resultant solution was introduced drop-by-drop into 200 ml of the solution and mixed at 80 °C for 30 min. The obtained mixture was kept in an oven at 90 °C for overnight. Further, the dried sample was placed in a muffle furnace for 1 h at 520 °C (ramp rate = 2.75 °C min−1) and the subsequent powder was first crushed, then washed thoroughly with water, and kept for overnight at 90 °C to load iron oxide in BCN (Fe-BCN). For the preparation of 10 wt. % cobalt oxide-loaded BCN (Co-BCN), instead of iron precursor, 0.5 g of cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Sigma, 99.5 % pure) was mixed in a 50 ml deionized water and ultra-sonicated for 5 min. The remaining procedure was the same as of Fe-BCN to prepare cobalt oxide-loaded BCN (Co-BCN). Characterization of catalysts A Rigaku X-ray diffractometer equipped with a Cu Kα anode (λ= 0.1518 nm) was used to acquire X-ray diffraction patterns of as-synthesized and spent catalysts. The working voltage was 10 kV, and the rate of scan was 2 ° min−1 from 2θ value of 20° to 90° Ammonia temperature programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) tests on the as-synthesized catalysts were carried out using Micrometrics, 3 FLEX equipment. All catalysts were firstly degassed for 1 h at 400 °C in a helium (He) environment before being cooled to 50 °C to allow ammonia to adsorb. In helium atmosphere, ammonia was desorbed by elevating the temperature from 50 °C to 700 °C at a ramp rate of 10 °C min−1. To evaluate the actual weight % of metal loaded to the catalysts, we performed inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) (7800, Agilent, USA). Initially, we need to digest all the catalysts. To digest the samples, we have taken 0.1 g of sample and added 10 ml of 1:1 HNO3. Then, solution was subjected to 95 °C for 15 min and then cooled to 25 °C. Then, 3 ml of concentrated HNO3 was added and again heated for 30 min to make the sample half of its original quantity. Then, we added 3 ml of HCl and heated for 15 min at 95 °C. Next, we added 3 ml of 30 % H2O2 and heated for 15 min. Again, we added 3 ml of 30 % H2O2, heated until effervescence subsidized. Afterwards, we added 10 ml of de-ionized (DI) water and heated the sample mixture. Now, we cooled the sample mixture and made up to 100 ml by adding DI water and filtered the digested sample. For ICP-MS study, we diluted the digested sample to 1000 times by DI water to make the elements concentration in ppb level. A JEOL-JEM 2100 plus electron microscope was used to get high-resolution details of lattice planes in the pristine catalysts. The operating voltage for the high-resolution transmission electron microscope (HRTEM) instrument was 200 keV and was integrated with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX). EDX was employed to obtain the spatial distribution of elements in the catalysts. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement was done on a PHI 5000 Versa Prob II, FEI instrument. The spectrometer was equipped with Al Kα anode (1486.6 eV). The narrow spectra of C1s, B1s, N1s, Co2p, and Fe2p were acquired and all the binding energies were refenced to the adventitious carbon signal at 284.8 eV. All Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) signals with 32 scans were recorded using a Thermo Scientific Nicolet iS50 infrared spectrometer, operated in transmittance mode at a resolution of 4 cm−1. Prior to that, background spectrum with 64 scans were collected at the same resolution. Also, to monitor the temperature distribution inside the reactor during plasma-ignition condition, an IR thermography (FLIR A655sc camera) was employed. Using a PerkinElmer STA 6000, Thermogravimetry Differential Thermal Analysis (TG/DTA) of fresh and used catalysts was conducted in a pin-holed aluminium crucible. The crucible was heated from 30 to 550 °C at 10 °C min−1 under argon flow (rate = 20 ml min−1). IR analysis of product stream Interestingly, to get an insight of species formed during the ammonia synthesis reaction, we employed Nicolet iS50 FTIR spectrometer (Make: Thermo scientific). To analyse the vent gas from NTP-assisted reaction, we attached HARRICK Praying Mantis chamber to spectrometer. Mercury cadmium telluride (MCT), chilled by liquid nitrogen, was used as a detector for obtaining the spectra. We first placed the KBr powder inside the reaction chamber and then connected the outlet of the DBD reactor to the high temperature reaction chamber. Initially, background spectra were collected when 40 ml min−1 of N2 and H2 mixture in 1:3 ratio was directly passed via the DBD reactor to the reaction chamber of praying mantis, without plasma-ignition. Here, the background spectra were acquired with 64 scans and at 4 cm−1 resolutions. Afterwards, the NTP was turned on and the sample spectra were taken with a step increase of 2 min in a process of 10 min. Results and discussion Characterization of as-synthesized catalysts Fig. 1 (a) illustrates the XRD patterns for as-prepared catalysts. Notably, the characteristic peaks of g-C3N4 (GCN) at 2 θ = 13 ∘ ( d − s p a c i n g = 0.682 n m ) and 2 θ = 27 . 5 ∘ ( d − s p a c i n g = 0.326 n m ) are viewed in the BCN sample. The (100) and (002) planes correspond to the in-plane structural repeating nitride motifs [47] and interlayer assembling of conjugated aromatic rings [48], respectively. The XRD pattern of GCN is provided in Fig. S1. Further, a close inspection of the (002) peak in the BCN catalyst, illustrate an apparent shift towards left (comparing GCN) from 27 . 5 ∘ t o 27 . 1 ∘ , which could be because of replacement of C or N by B atoms [49,50]. Comparing GCN, intensity of the peak (002) for BCN was suppressed, which could be because of poor crystalline nature of BCN. Apparently, the (100) peak of BCN disappeared after loading of Fe or Co, that implies that these metal species were successfully introduced into the in-planes of BCN. To verify this, we conducted the ICP-MS experiments and found the existence of Fe and Co in Fe-BCN and Co-BCN samples, respectively. The detailed results are given in suppl. Table S1. Next, we collected HRTEM and SAED images to gain an understanding about the lattice planes of the as-synthesized catalysts (Fig. 1(b)). In fact, the SAED pattern discloses low crystallinity of the BCN catalyst. This result is in line with the XRD pattern and HRTEM image. No apparent crystal fringe is observed for BCN catalyst, which discloses different degrees of structural distortion and amorphous nature of the sample. In Fe-BCN, the presence of lattice fringes with 0.273 nm spacing resemble to the (014) plane of Fe2O3 (Y. lei [51]). Similarly, the (220) plane with 0.285 nm spacings corresponding to Co3O4, exists in the Co-BCN catalyst [52]. The elemental mapping of a selected area in the as-prepared catalysts is provided in Fig.S2. This result suggests that the spatial distribution of Co on the BCN surface is more uniform than that of the Fe active sites, which could positively influence the catalytic activity of Co. Furthermore, the NH3-TPD profile of pristine catalysts is shown in Fig. 1(c). No signal was observed for any catalysts below 600 °C.Comparing other catalysts, BCN exhibit intense signal above 600 °C, implying that this catalyst offers higher number of strong acidic sites. As is known, basic ammonia gas generated during the process, would efficiently bound to the strong acid sites of the catalyst [53]. This would lower the ammonia concentration in the product outlet, and most of the formed ammonia would stick to the catalyst. Herein, we reduced the acidic sites of BCN by doping Fe or Co species. Specifically, Co-BCN demonstrate weak acidic sites over the surface, which significantly suppress the adsorption of ammonia on its surface. This implies that transition metals lowered quantity, and strength of the acid sites in the BCN catalyst. The trend of NH3 desorption is BCN (2.86mmolg−1 NH3) > Fe-BCN (2.20mmolg−1 NH3) > Co-BCN (2.07mmolg−1 NH3). As-prepared catalysts were analysed by XPS, for understanding of the surface chemical composition. Herein, the survey spectra find B, C and N in all the catalysts and also, the transition metals such as Fe and Co are present. The deconvolution of C1s, N1s, B1s, Fe2p and Co2p spectra is given in Fig. 2 . In Fig. 2(a), the deconvolution of C1s spectra illustrated the presence of C = C bond and NC = N bond at 284.8 and 288.1 eV, respectively. Also, one peak at 285.8 eV can be ascribed to C = N in BCN catalyst. Another small peak at 286.2 eV can be attributed to CO bond, present in Fe-BCN catalyst [54]. Two apparent peaks can be seen in the deconvoluted spectra of N1s in as-synthesized catalysts (Fig. 2(b)). These peaks at 398.5 and 399.5 eV, can be ascribed to sp3 and sp2 NC bonds, respectively [55]. Similarly, in BCN catalyst, the deconvolution of B1s narrow spectra resulted into two obvious peaks at 191.6 and 192.7 eV (Fig. 2(c)). The presence of B-O bonds accounts for the peak at 191.6 eV in the B1s spectra and peak at 192.7 eV corresponds to CBO2 [56]. Other catalysts show peak corresponding to B-O bond on the surface. Deconvolution of Fe2p spectra for Fe-BCN catalyst disclose the presence of Fe3+ and Fe2+ oxidation state of Fe (Fig. 2(d)). The peak at 719.1 eV corresponds to Fe2+ and other peaks at 711.4 and 725.2 eV illustrate the existence of Fe3+ of Fe2p3/2 and Fe2p1/2 peak. The other peak at 731.1 eV in the spectra belongs to the satellite peak of Fe3+ [57]. The resulting peaks from the deconvolution of Co 2p spectra of Co-BCN catalyst correspond to Co-Nx and Co3O4. Co3O4 result to the peaks at 780.1 and 796.5 eV [58]. In addition, two satellite peaks at 786.0 and 802.6 eV could be assigned to cobalt oxides (Fig. 2(e)). This result reveals that some cobalt oxides are generated during calcination of the catalysts. Co-N x can be assigned to the peak at 782.2 eV [59]. Reaction results Effect of process parameters The effect of feed ratio (N2:H2) on NH3 generation is illustrated in Fig. 3 (a) with the total gas flow rate, time, and SEI being 80 ml min−1, 10 min, and 17.28 kJ L−1, respectively. The feed ratios (N2:H2) vary from 2:1 to 1:5. The feed ratio of 1:3 (N2:H2) resulted to optimum formation rate and yield for ammonia ca. 592.2 ± 15.0 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 and 0.55 % , respectively. It can be seen that the highest rate of ammonia generation occurs with a feed composition equal to the stoichiometric ratio in the H-B process. This is in line with the previous reports [60–62]. In general, nitrogen dissociation is regarded as the rate-determining step for the H-B process. Herein, more generation of plasma-assisted N(ads) would facilitate NH3 synthesis, which could be possible with large number of nitrogen molecules. However, too high N2:H2 ratios, i.e., lower hydrogen content would drastically reduce the electron density and temperature, as also suggested by others [41,60,63]. Such lower shift in the mean electron energy distribution would lead to inefficient nitrogen dissociation or, NH formation. Next, the influence of residence time on ammonia formation rate was examined, for our continuous custom-designed NTP reactor with feed ratio of 1:3 (N2:H2) and SEI of 17.28kJL−1 (Fig. 3(b)). The overall gas flow rate increased from 40 ml min−1 to 120 ml min−1. The maximum ammonia production rate was 679.8 ± 12.6 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 for 120 ml min−1. And the minimum rate was 387.6 ± 10.2 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , observed at 40 ml min−1. Previous reports suggest that at a longer residence time, because of the low feed flow rate, number of effective collisions between reactive species significantly increase resulting into a higher ammonia formation rate, which implies higher ammonia concentration in the reactor (S. [31]; J. [64,65]). In contrast, we observed a reverse phenomenon, which was also reported by others [41,66]. Herein, at higher residence time, lower rate for ammonia formation was monitored. This is because NTP could facilitate the undesired decomposition of generated ammonia to nitrogen and hydrogen gas [41,67,68]. Additionally, the NH3 yield ( %) decreased from ∼0.72 % to ∼0.42 % under the chosen reaction conditions, mainly owing to the dilution of ammonia concentration in large amount of reactive species (or, high gas flow rates). Comparing this result with previous report by Peng et al., here, under identical conditions, we observed ammonia yield of 0.61 % for the total flow rate of 60 ml min−1 which was higher than that of Peng's group (0.25 %) [68] . Similarly, the effect of SEI was explored at overall gas flow rate of 40 ml min−1 and N2:H2 vol ratio of 1:3. Fig. 3(c) unveils the NH3 formation rate with varying SEI from 11.52 to 20.16 kJ L−1. Undoubtedly, discharge power is a crucial factor that greatly governs the intensity of plasma inside a DBD reactor and subsequently, the formation rate of ammonia [69,70]. At high discharge power, the number of plasma-activated nitrogen and hydrogen species are huge, which could combine to form ammonia. For instance, the ammonia formation rate at 20.16 kJ L−1 was 462.0 ± 20.0 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , about 1.8-folds higher than at 11.52 kJ L−1. At a fixed flow rate of 40 ml min−1, the NH3 yield ( %) would increase with discharge power and reach at 0.86 %. Performance of as-prepared catalysts towards ammonia generation As shown in Fig. 4 (a), blank experiments disclose ammonia synthesis rate of ca. 462.0 ± 20.0 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , at 20.16 kJ L−1. The reaction system loaded with as-synthesized catalysts exhibit higher rate for ammonia synthesis. The temperature profile inside the NTP reactor is given in Fig. S3. In comparison, the NTP-assisted ammonia synthesis reactions with catalysts demonstrate a remarkedly greater rates than that without catalyst. This signifies the synergy between NTP and catalyst, to increase the overall efficiency. For instance, at 20.16 kJ L−1, GCN, BCN and Fe-BCN present an ammonia production rate of ca. 843.7 ± 11.4 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , 1027.1 ± 14.6 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , and 1608.0 ± 32.1 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , respectively. In particular, at SEI of 20.16 kJ L−1 and overall gas flow rate of 40 ml min−1, Co-BCN catalyst demonstrate four-folds higher rate than that for the blank experiment. Fig. S4 presents ammonia yield ( %) results for without and with catalysts. The data reveals that Co-BCN generates 3.8 % of ammonia under the reactant gas flow rate of 40mlmin−1 and SEI of 20.16kJL−1. Furthermore, as also described in the previous section, increase in discharge power facilitates ammonia synthesis. For example, at 20.16 kJ L−1, Co-BCN show the ammonia synthesis rate of 1883.2 ± 19.6 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , which is higher than that at 17.28 kJ L−1 ( ∼ 1392.6 ± 23.0 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 ) . Such increasing effect can be because of the increase in concentration of plasma-activated reactants, which readily combine to form ammonia at high discharge power. Additionally, the inclusion of transition metals helps to increase the ammonia synthesis rates. To understand the influence of total flow rate in the plasma-assisted ammonia production, we systematically conducted a series of experiments (Fig. 4(b)). Interestingly, a similar trend of the catalytic performance can be observed at higher total flow rate of gases (∼120 ml min−1). Co-BCN shows maximum ammonia synthesis rate of 2478.3 ± 26.9 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , at 20.16 kJ L−1 and energy efficiency of 2.09 g-NH3 kWh−1. Next to Co-BCN, Fe-BCN and BCN demonstrate ammonia synthesis rate of 2129.2 ± 24.7 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 and 1522.0 ± 33.5 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 , respectively. The energy efficiency of the Fe-BCN and BCN are 1.79 and 1.28 g-NH3 kWh−1, respectively, which are comparable to the previous report [68]. On the other hand, under the same reaction conditions, GCN displays ammonia synthesis rate of only 1239.4 ± 21.6 μ m o l g − 1 h − 1 . Comparing the results at different conditions (Fig. 4 (a, b)), it is apparent that the addition of boron to GCN enhanced the ammonia synthesis rate. Such observation could be primarily attributed to the empty orbitals of boron which could efficiently bind or activate inert nitrogen molecules. In the blank experiment, ∼2.89-times lower ammonia synthesis rate than Co-BCN was noticed. The promotional effect of higher discharge power was apparent at higher total gas flow rate, relatively higher ammonia synthesis rate was observed. Notably, at high gas flow-rate, the external diffusion resistance for gases to reach to the catalyst surface could be eliminated, which enhanced the ammonia synthesis rate (Fig. 4 (a, b)). Table S2 illustrates a comparison of our results with recent reports. To further explore the possible reason for difference in the catalytic performance for Fe-BCN and Co-BCN catalysts, we carefully analysed the NH3-TPD and XPS results. NH3-TPD result displayed the presence of fewer acidic sites over Co-BCN than that of Fe-BCN and BCN catalysts (Fig. 1(c)). Since ammonia is basic, any catalyst with strong acidic sites could offer surface to adsorb ammonia. Consequently, ammonia in the effluent stream would be relatively lower. Herein, under the same reaction conditions, Co-BCN exhibit higher ammonia synthesis rate, partially owing to the unavailability of strong acidic sites on its surface. Additionally, it could also be observed that Co has higher electronegativity than Fe, which suggests that the electrons produced during the NTP can readily adsorb over the surface of Co-BCN than the Fe-BCN (see XPS results in Fig. 2). Since a relatively low number of electrons could participate in the reaction, lower ammonia synthesis rate was noticed. Moreover, the distribution of Co over the surface of BCN is more uniform than that of Fe (Fig. S2); this could contribute to increase the catalytic efficiency of Co-BCN comparing Fe-BCN. Combining experimental results, it is clear that doping of Fe- and Co- were beneficial to promote the activity of BCN catalyst. Of the doped catalysts, Co-BCN demonstrate higher activity under the chosen reaction conditions. Role of lattice N in the tested catalysts Next, we explored the role of lattice N in BCN samples for the formation of ammonia. To address this question, we carefully conducted two separate experiments for ammonia synthesis under pure gaseous streams of (i) N2 and (ii) H2, respectively. The overall flow rate of different gas feed was 40 ml min−1, with SEI of 20.16 kJ L−1. To check for ammonia generation during the NTP process, the reactor outlet was flown into the Nessler's reagent to identify the colour change. In the experiments with only N2 flow, there was no colour change; indicating that no ammonia was formed. On the contrary, the dark-brown precipitate was observed for only-H2 flow experiments, suggesting the interaction of N in BCN with plasma-activated hydrogen gas to generate ammonia. The corresponding formation rate of ammonia was 263.8 μmolg−1h−1. This result indicates the possibility of Mars-van Krevelen mechanism, as reported with other thermal catalysts [[21,71]. Interestingly, in the subsequent runs, the ammonia formation rate was drastically reduced, implying that the nitrogen from BCN sample was consumed with reaction time (see suppl. Fig. S5). IR spectroscopy study To further reveal the role of plasma in generating ammonia, we conducted IR study with and without catalysts. Corresponding results are provided in Fig. 5 (a, b). Evidently, the two distinct absorption peaks at 965 cm−1 and 930 cm−1 confirm the presence of ammonia [72]. These peaks are ascribed as ϑ 2 vibration of ammonia molecules in the gas phase. Importantly, these peaks are observed only in the plasma-ignition condition. Under the NTP-off condition, the intensity of ammonia peaks became weak, indicating that no further ammonia synthesis reaction took place. With time, the signal disappeared, implying no further ammonia generation. Comparing the relative intensity changes for blank and Co-BCN experiments, a progressive increase in the intensity at 930 cm−1 was observed (Fig. 5(c)). Comparing blank experiment, a steeper increase in intensity was apparent for Co-BCN catalyst at a later stage of plasma-exposure, implying promotional effect of catalyst material (see inset). However, a slow decline in the intensity was observed for the catalytic experiment. Such results disclose that the generated ammonia gas adsorbed over the Co-BCN for a longer time relative to the blank experiment, which could be primarily because of the presence of acidic sites on the catalyst surface. Characterization of spent catalysts It is important to comprehend the structural, chemical, and thermal stability of spent catalysts. Therefore, we conducted an in-depth study in order to acquire an insight into the change in physical and chemical properties of the spent catalysts, and the findings are shown in Fig. 6 . Firstly, (002) peak of BCN remain intact, with no further shift towards lower or higher angle (Fig. 6(a)). This implies the absence of any stresses, initiated during the NTP process. Other catalysts also unveil no apparent shift in the peak position and intensity of the (002) peak. Next, we conducted FTIR study for the fresh and spent catalysts. Corresponding IR spectra of BCN and Fe-BCN are provided in suppl. Fig. S6. In Fig. 6(b), the peak range 3500–3000 cm−1 resembles to the stretching vibration of NH of amino group and OH vibration caused by adsorbed water on the surface for all the catalysts. Other peaks at 1640, 1572, 1542, 1463, 1408, 1316, 1236 and 1206 cm−1 reveal C = N stretching vibrations mode [73]. Additional peaks at 1384, 1165 and 780 cm−1 attributed to the stretching of B-N, B-N-O bonds and bending of B-N-B bond, respectively [74]. IR signals at 1280 and 1335 cm−1 can be ascribed to B-C stretching and B-O vibration in BO3, respectively. The addition of metal in BCN catalyst discloses a signal attributed to CO stretching at 2164 cm−1. The spent catalysts do not show any significant change in the spectra for all the catalysts, which reveal no structural change during the process of ammonia synthesis. We also performed XPS study over the spent catalysts and observed the presence of C- NH x (x = 1,2) species over surface of the catalysts. It is to note that peak at 400.7 eV corresponds to C- NH x (x = 1,2) in spent BCN sample and 401.1 eV can be attributed to the CNH species present in the Co-BCN catalyst (see Fig. 6(c)) [75]. The assignment of NH species in Fe-BCN is given in Fig. S7. Comparing other tested catalysts, higher proportions of NH were detected on the surface of BCN, implying that these species are more stable on the surface of BCN, and thus not easily desorbed. This also could be the reason for relatively slow rate of ammonia formation by BCN. These observations are in line with NH3-TPD (Fig. 1(c)). Furthermore, we performed TG/DTA analysis to evaluate the thermal stability of fresh and spent catalysts. Fig. 6(d) shows a representative plot for Co-BCN catalyst. Apparently, the Co-BCN starts to decompose at ca. 135 °C with weight loss of 24.12 %, mainly because of dehydration [76]. Next, the thermal deformation begins at around 262 °C, which is subsequently followed by the thermal decomposition of monolayer structure or deformation of heptazine-units of GCN [77]. Data of other tested catalysts is given in suppl. Fig. S8. Herein, the maximum temperature attained inside the DBD reactor is close to 75 °C and in this temperature region, no significant difference was observed for pristine and spent Co-BCN catalysts. However, at high temperature, difference in weight loss ( %) could also be because of the desorption of surface adsorbed NH species. Plausible reaction mechanism A strategically designed catalyst can remarkedly increase rates of NTP-assisted ammonia synthesis reactions. NTP catalysis is generally a complex process because it involves species transit through the gas and solid phases, species ionization, plasma discharge, and surface reactions. In addition to the type of plasma discharge and micro-discharges in porous catalysts, catalysts strongly influence the localized electric field. The adsorption and surface reactions are influenced by the interaction between the catalyst and plasma. In Fig. 7 , a plausible reaction mechanism consisting of two potential routes is provided. Combining the experimental findings, it is obvious that low residence time, high power, and optimum feed ratio are crucial to achieve a greater production rate of ammonia. Under NTP conditions, the dissociation energy for strong nitrogen molecules is typically achieved by high energy electrons (1–10 eV) [78,79]. Further, the catalyst provides surface for N(ads) and H(ads) to combine to form ammonia, as suggested by the L-H mechanism. Interestingly, loading of metal species helps to increase the number of energetic electrons and energy injected into the plasma; that subsequently promote the electron-impact reactions. This work also emphasizes the role of acid sites in increasing the ammonia synthesis rates. For instance, Co-BCN catalyst lacks strong acid sites, which helps to suppress adsorption of ammonia over its surface (see Fig. 1(c)). The absence of C- NH x (x = 1,2) species on the surface of spent Co-BCN catalyst, clearly signifies the role of acidic sites in enhancing the overall ammonia synthesis rate (see Fig. 6(c)). In summary, transition metals increase the electrons-catalyst interactions and also, facilitate ammonia desorption from the catalysts surface. Moreover, under NTP conditions and only H2 flow, we observed the hydrogenation of lattice nitrogen in BCN catalyst to ammonia. Such findings demonstrate that ammonia could also be formed via MvK mechanism. Conclusion In a custom-built DBD reactor, plasma-assisted synthesis of ammonia was conducted using transition metal-loaded boron graphitic carbon nitride at ambient pressure and close to room temperature. The ammonia synthesis rate was significantly enhanced by the as-prepared catalysts in the order: Co-BCN> Fe-BCN > BCN> blank. It is demonstrated that factors such as low residence time, high power, and stoichiometric ratio of feed are important to achieve higher ammonia synthesis rates. Herein, Co-BCN demonstrated a rate of ∼ 2.48 m m o l g − 1 h − 1 for ammonia synthesis, which was ca. 2.89-folds higher than that of plasma only. A detailed characterization was conducted for as-synthesized catalysts. The result depicts that the weak acid sites of Co-BCN can positively accelerate ammonia synthesis rates, owing to the ability to reduce adsorption of formed ammonia molecules from the catalysts surface. Interestingly, product outlet was also monitored using the IR spectroscopy, which disclosed the existence of ammonia peaks, only in the plasma-ignition conditions. The results suggest that dual mechanisms such as L-H and MvK mechanisms could co-exist to form ammonia. Most importantly, this work demonstrates the consumption of lattice nitrogen in BCN catalyst via hydrogenation process to ammonia, which implies the possibility of MvK mechanism. coredata.dc:description: We report nonthermal plasma-assisted catalytic ammonia synthesis from N2 and H2 molecules at near ambient conditions in a custom-built coaxial dielectric barrier discharge plasma reactor. Here, we strategically designed catalysts to facilitate dissociation of strong nitrogen bond and desorption of NH3 molecules. This work demonstrates the use of empty orbitals of boron doped in graphitic carbon nitride (BCN) to activate nitrogen molecules, by creating electron-deficient sites, under nonthermal plasma conditions. Transition metals (Co and Fe) further contribute to the ammonia generation by altering the amount of weak acid sites of the BCN catalyst. As a result, at 20.16 kJ L−1, the maximum ammonia synthesis rate of ∼ 2.48 m m o l g − 1 h − 1 was achieved by Co-BCN that corresponds to energy efficiency of 2.09 g-NH3 kWh−1, which was ca. 2.89-folds higher than that of plasma only. Evidently, dual mechanisms at play, leading to enhanced ammonia synthesis rates. Our strategy of tailoring catalyst structure provides a roadmap for engineering synergy with nonthermal plasma towards targeted applications.
coredata.dc:title: Tailoring the surface acidity of catalyst to enhance nonthermal plasma-assisted ammonia synthesis rates
